0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Merck has decided to stop production of MUMPSVAX(R) (Mumps Virus Vaccine Live) and will continue to manufacture only the combination vaccine.
  • Mumps; Prophylaxis: 0.5 mL SUBQ

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Merck has decided to stop production of MUMPSVAX(R) (Mumps Virus Vaccine Live) and will continue to manufacture only the combination vaccine.
  • safety and effectiveness in infants below the age of 12 mo have not been established
  • Mumps; Prophylaxis: (12 mo and older) 0.5 mL SUBQ, recommended to give at 12 to 15 mo

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Merck has decided to stop production of MUMPSVAX(R) (Mumps Virus Vaccine Live) and will continue to manufacture only the combination vaccine [1].
  • Mumps; Prophylaxis

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• Active, untreated tuberculosis
  • Acute febrile illness (not including minor illness with or without low-grade fever)
  • Blood dyscrasias, leukemia, lymphomas, bone marrow malignancy
  • Hypersensitivity to neomycin
  • Hypersensitivity to vaccine components including gelatin
  • Immunosuppressive therapy (corticosteroids, antineoplastic agents, irradiation) (does not apply to corticosteroid replacement therapy)
  • Pregnancy
  • Pregnancy should be avoided for 28 days postvaccination based on Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommendations; pregnancy should be avoided for 3 months postvaccination based on manufacturer recommendations
  • Primary, acquired, or familial immunodeficiency

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Blood/plasma transfusions, or administration of immune globulin; defer vaccination for at least 3 months
  • Fever may occur following vaccination
  • History of contact dermatitis to neomycin
  • HIV-infected patients
  • Hypersensitivity to eggs
  • Special care should be taken to ensure that the injection does not enter a blood vessel
  • Temporary depression of tuberculin skin test sensitivity
  • Thrombocytopenia

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Injection site reaction, Rash
  • Immunologic:Lymphadenopathy
  • Respiratory:Common cold
  • Other:Fever
Serious
  • Dermatologic:Stevens-Johnson syndrome
  • Hematologic:Thrombocytopenia
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis
  • Neurologic:Encephalitis, Febrile seizure, Guillain-Barr syndrome, Association with vaccine unlikely
  • Ophthalmic:Optic neuritis, Palsy of conjugate gaze

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Systemic: Following subcutaneous injection, mumps vaccine produces a modified, noncommunicable mumps infection and provides active immunity to mumps .

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    (injection) for SUBQ use only; do not inject IV
  • Subcutaneous
    • do not give concurrently with immune globulin
    • administer in outer aspect of upper arm
    • reconstitute with supplied diluent, shake well
    • should be given one month before or after administration of other live viral vaccines

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Recommend female patients of child-bearing age use reliable contraception to avoid pregnancy at least 3 months post-vaccination.
  • This drug may cause lymphadenopathy or a cold.
  • Advise patient to immediately report signs/symptoms of Stevens-Johnson syndrome (flu-like symptoms, spreading red rash, or skin/mucous membrane blistering).
  • Patient should also report high fever, convulsions, or signs/symptoms of thrombocytopenia or optic neuritis.
  • Instruct patient to avoid having other vaccinations one month before or after administration of this vaccine.
